modules.title: Ethics and Trust in the Investment Profession

concepts.title: Ethics Defined
concepts.desc: Ethics: set of shared beliefs about what is good or acceptable behavior. Goes beyond legal requirements. A code of ethics communicates an organization's values.

concepts.title: Trust in Investment Management
concepts.desc: Clients entrust assets to professionals, creating an asymmetric relationship. Trust is the foundation of the investment profession.

concepts.title: Professionalism
concepts.desc: Professions are distinguished by: specialized knowledge, standards of practice, a code of ethics, accountability to a governing body, and service to society.

concepts.title: Ethical vs Legal Standards
concepts.desc: Ethical standards are often MORE stringent than legal standards. Legal ≠ ethical. Some actions are legal but unethical; some laws may be unjust.

concepts.title: Ethical Decision-Making Framework
concepts.desc: Identify → Consider → Act → Reflect. Consider: who is affected? What are the relevant facts? What ethical principles apply? What are the alternatives?

concepts.title: Challenges to Ethical Conduct
concepts.desc: Overconfidence, situational influences (loyalty, conformity, incrementalism), rationalization. Being aware of biases helps guard against ethical lapses.

decisions.question: How to resolve an ethical dilemma?
use: Apply the ethical decision-making framework systematically
Choose the action most consistent with the Code of Ethics and professional duty
avoid: Choosing the legal minimum when a higher ethical standard applies

pitfalls: Legal compliance is NECESSARY but NOT SUFFICIENT for ethical behavior
Situational influences (peer pressure, authority) can erode ethical judgment
Incrementalism: small ethical compromises can lead to major violations over time
Overconfidence in one's own ethical judgment without systematic reflection

questions.question: Ethical conduct in the investment profession requires:
options: Compliance with laws and adherence to ethical principles that may exceed legal requirements
Following industry norms regardless of law
Maximizing client returns at all costs
questions.explanation: Ethics goes beyond mere legal compliance. CFA standards often require behavior that exceeds what the law mandates.

questions.question: Which of the following is a challenge to ethical conduct?
options: Having a formal code of ethics
Situational influences such as loyalty to an employer
questions.explanation: Situational influences (loyalty, conformity, authority) can pressure individuals to compromise ethical standards.

questions.question: The ethical decision-making framework begins with:
options: Identifying the ethical issue and relevant facts
questions.explanation: The framework starts with identifying the ethical dilemma, gathering relevant facts, and considering who is affected before proceeding to action.

modules.title: Code of Ethics and Standards of Professional Conduct

concepts.title: Code of Ethics (6 Components)
concepts.desc: 1) Act with integrity, competence, diligence, respect. 2) Place client interests above own. 3) Use reasonable care, independent judgment. 4) Practice and encourage ethical behavior. 5) Promote integrity of capital markets. 6) Maintain and improve professional competence.

concepts.title: Standard I: Professionalism
concepts.desc: I(A) Knowledge of the Law, I(B) Independence & Objectivity, I(C) Misrepresentation, I(D) Misconduct, I(E) Competence.

concepts.title: Standard II: Integrity of Capital Markets
concepts.desc: II(A) Material Nonpublic Information (MNPI), II(B) Market Manipulation. Protect market fairness.

concepts.title: Standard III: Duties to Clients
concepts.desc: III(A) Loyalty, Prudence, Care. III(B) Fair Dealing. III(C) Suitability. III(D) Performance Presentation. III(E) Preservation of Confidentiality.

concepts.title: Standard IV: Duties to Employers
concepts.desc: IV(A) Loyalty. IV(B) Additional Compensation Arrangements. IV(C) Responsibilities of Supervisors.

concepts.title: Standards V-VII
concepts.desc: V: Investment Analysis (diligence, communication, record retention). VI: Conflicts of Interest (disclosure, priority of transactions, referral fees). VII: Responsibilities as CFA Member (conduct, reference to CFA Institute).

decisions.question: When laws conflict with the Code and Standards?
use: Follow the STRICTER of the law or the Code and Standards
If local law is stricter, follow local law
If the Code is stricter, follow the Code
avoid: Assuming local law always takes precedence
Ignoring the Code just because local law permits an action

pitfalls: Always follow the STRICTER requirement — whether it's the law or the CFA Standards
Independence & Objectivity: gifts, travel, and compensation can compromise independence
Fair dealing means all clients treated FAIRLY (not necessarily identically or simultaneously)
Members must know the law but are NOT required to be legal experts

questions.question: When local law and the CFA Code and Standards conflict, a member should:
options: Follow local law in all cases
Follow the CFA Standards in all cases
Follow the stricter of the two requirements
questions.explanation: Members must follow the stricter of local law or the Code and Standards. This ensures the highest ethical standard is met.

questions.question: Standard III(B) Fair Dealing requires that members:
options: Give all clients identical investment recommendations simultaneously
Treat all clients fairly when disseminating information and recommendations
Provide the same level of service to all clients
questions.explanation: Fair dealing means treating all clients fairly, not necessarily identically. Different service levels are acceptable if disclosed and not discriminatory.

questions.question: Which standard addresses the use of material nonpublic information?
questions.explanation: Standard II(A) Material Nonpublic Information prohibits trading or causing others to trade on MNPI.

concepts.title: I(A) Knowledge of the Law
concepts.desc: Must understand and comply with applicable laws and regulations. Follow the stricter of law or CFA Standards. Must dissociate from violations.

concepts.title: I(B) Independence & Objectivity
concepts.desc: Must not offer/accept gifts that could compromise independence. Research must be free from issuer influence. Disclose conflicts.

concepts.title: I(C) Misrepresentation
concepts.desc: Must not misstate facts about investment analysis, recommendations, actions, or professional qualifications. Includes plagiarism.

concepts.title: II(A) Material Nonpublic Information
concepts.desc: Cannot trade or cause others to trade on MNPI. Mosaic theory: combining public and non-material nonpublic info IS allowed.

concepts.title: III(A) Loyalty, Prudence, Care
concepts.desc: Fiduciary duty: act in client's best interest. Determine who the client is. Exercise prudence and care in investment decisions.

concepts.title: III(C) Suitability
concepts.desc: Must gather client information (IPS) and ensure recommendations are suitable for the client's situation, risk tolerance, and objectives.

concepts.title: IV(A) Loyalty to Employer
concepts.desc: Must act in employer's interest, not take proprietary information when leaving. Can prepare to leave but not solicit clients before departure.

concepts.title: VI(A-C) Conflicts of Interest
concepts.desc: Disclose all conflicts (compensation, ownership, board seats). Priority of transactions: clients > employer > personal. Disclose referral fees.

decisions.question: Mosaic Theory: When can you trade on nonpublic info?
use: Mosaic theory: combine public info + non-material nonpublic info to form a conclusion
Conclusions from public analysis, industry research, expert network (public channels)
avoid: Trading on a single piece of MATERIAL nonpublic information

pitfalls: Mosaic theory is ALLOWED — combining non-material nonpublic info with public info
Dissociation from violations: report up the chain, refuse to participate, ultimately resign if necessary
Gifts to clients are different from gifts from clients — both can create conflicts
Personal trading: transaction priority is Clients > Employer > Employee
Record retention: maintain records to support investment analysis and actions (typically 7 years)
Referral fees must be disclosed to clients BEFORE entering the relationship

examples.title: Mosaic Theory Application
examples.problem: An analyst combines data from public filings, channel checks at retail stores (public), and a conversation with a supplier who says "orders are steady" (non-material nonpublic). Can she trade?
examples.solution: Yes. No single piece of information is material and nonpublic. The analyst is using the mosaic theory — combining various public and non-material nonpublic information to reach her own investment conclusion.

questions.question: Under the mosaic theory, an analyst may:
options: Trade on material nonpublic information if combined with public info
Combine non-material nonpublic info with public info to form an investment conclusion
Share material nonpublic information with select clients
questions.explanation: Mosaic theory allows analysts to combine various pieces of public and NON-MATERIAL nonpublic information to reach investment conclusions.

questions.question: An analyst discovers her firm is violating securities law. Her first action should be:
options: Report the violation to her supervisor or compliance department
questions.explanation: Standard I(A): First report up the chain (supervisor, compliance). Dissociate from the activity. Resignation is a last resort if the firm fails to act.

questions.question: Priority of transactions under Standard VI(B) is:
questions.explanation: Client interests come first, then employer, then personal. This prevents front-running and ensures fiduciary duty is met.

questions.question: A portfolio manager is leaving her firm. She may:
options: Take client lists and solicit clients before resigning
Prepare to leave but not solicit clients until after departure
Copy proprietary models to use at her new firm
Contact clients secretly to redirect their assets
questions.explanation: Standard IV(A): Members can prepare to leave but must not solicit employer's clients or take proprietary information before departure.

questions.question: Which of the following is required under Standard III(C) Suitability?
options: Recommending the highest-returning investment to all clients
Gathering information about each client's financial situation and objectives before making recommendations
Ensuring all clients hold the same portfolio
questions.explanation: Suitability requires knowing the client — their financial situation, risk tolerance, objectives, constraints — before making any recommendation.

concepts.title: GIPS Overview
concepts.desc: Global Investment Performance Standards: voluntary, ethical standards for calculating and presenting investment performance. Goal: fair, comparable reporting.

concepts.title: Why GIPS Exists
concepts.desc: Without GIPS, firms could cherry-pick best-performing accounts. GIPS creates a level playing field for performance comparison across firms and countries.

concepts.title: Composites
concepts.desc: A composite groups all portfolios managed under a similar strategy. Firms MUST include all fee-paying, discretionary portfolios in appropriate composites.

concepts.title: GIPS Key Requirements
concepts.desc: Firm-wide compliance (cannot claim partial compliance). Must present at least 5 years of GIPS-compliant data (or since inception if < 5 years). Build to 10 years.

concepts.title: Verification
concepts.desc: Voluntary third-party review of GIPS compliance. Applies to the entire firm, not individual composites. Adds credibility but is not required.

decisions.question: When must a firm claim GIPS compliance?
use: Compliance is voluntary but once claimed, must apply firm-wide
Must include all actual, fee-paying, discretionary portfolios in composites
Must present performance net of trading costs at a minimum
avoid: Claiming GIPS compliance for only selected composites

pitfalls: GIPS compliance is ALL or NOTHING — no partial compliance allowed
All fee-paying discretionary portfolios MUST be included in at least one composite
Cannot link non-GIPS-compliant performance history to GIPS-compliant records
Verification is recommended but NOT required for GIPS compliance
Terminated portfolios must remain in the composite for the periods they were managed

questions.question: Under GIPS, a composite must include:
options: All actual, discretionary, fee-paying portfolios managed under the same strategy
Only portfolios above a minimum size
questions.explanation: Composites must include ALL actual, discretionary, fee-paying portfolios managed under a similar strategy. This prevents cherry-picking of results.

questions.question: GIPS verification is:
options: Required for composites with more than 10 portfolios
Voluntary and applies to the entire firm
questions.explanation: Verification is voluntary but recommended. If undertaken, it applies to the entire firm, not to individual composites.

questions.question: A firm claiming GIPS compliance must initially present at least:
questions.explanation: Firms must initially present at least 5 years of GIPS-compliant data, or since inception if the firm has been in existence less than 5 years, then build up to 10 years.

concepts.title: Applying the Code & Standards
concepts.desc: Real-world scenarios require judgment. Multiple standards may apply simultaneously. Focus on identifying which standards are relevant and what action is required.

concepts.title: Common Violation Patterns
concepts.desc: Front-running (trading ahead of clients), churning (excessive trading for commissions), misrepresentation of credentials, selective disclosure, conflicts of interest.

concepts.title: Whistleblowing
concepts.desc: Report violations internally first (supervisor/compliance). If no action, escalate. External reporting may be required by law. Protect yourself legally.

concepts.title: Soft Dollar Standards
concepts.desc: Commissions used for research must benefit clients. Cannot use soft dollars for non-research expenses. Must disclose soft dollar arrangements.

concepts.title: Social Media & Communications
concepts.desc: Same standards apply to social media as traditional communications. Must be factual, not misleading, and include proper disclosures.

decisions.question: How to handle suspected ethics violations?
use: Identify which standard(s) are at issue
Report to supervisor or compliance officer
avoid: Immediately going public without internal reporting first

pitfalls: Front-running: trading personal account BEFORE executing client orders violates multiple standards
Churning: excessive trading to generate commissions violates loyalty, prudence, and care
Cannot use "I was told to do it" as a defense — personal responsibility remains
Social media posts are held to the same standards as formal research reports
Failing to disclose referral fees or compensation arrangements violates Standard VI

examples.title: Front-Running Scenario
examples.problem: A PM learns her firm will issue a buy recommendation on Stock X tomorrow. She buys shares in her personal account today. Which standards are violated?
examples.solution: Standard II(A) MNPI — the upcoming recommendation is material nonpublic info. Standard VI(B) Priority of Transactions — client trades must come first. Standard III(A) Loyalty, Prudence & Care — she must act in clients' best interest, not her own.

questions.question: An analyst buys shares in her personal account before her firm publishes a buy recommendation. This violates:
options: Only Standard VI(B) Priority of Transactions
No standards if she believed the stock was undervalued
questions.explanation: This is front-running, violating: II(A) MNPI (upcoming recommendation is material nonpublic), III(A) Loyalty to clients, and VI(B) Priority of transactions (clients first).

questions.question: A portfolio manager repeatedly buys and sells securities to generate commissions for his broker. This is known as:
questions.explanation: Churning is excessive trading designed to generate commissions rather than benefit the client. It violates Standard III(A) Loyalty, Prudence, and Care.

questions.question: Regarding soft dollar arrangements, members must ensure:
options: Research purchased benefits the clients whose commissions paid for it
Soft dollars are used for office expenses
Clients are not informed of the arrangement
questions.explanation: Soft dollar research must benefit the clients whose trading commissions pay for it. Arrangements must be disclosed to clients.

questions.question: A CFA charterholder posts an investment recommendation on social media without disclosing her firm or conflicts. This violates:
options: No standard — social media is personal
Standard V(B) Communication with Clients and Standard VI(A) Disclosure of Conflicts
Only if the recommendation is wrong
questions.explanation: Social media posts are held to the same standards as formal communications. Must disclose identity, firm, and conflicts of interest.
